banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Climate action should focus on communities, not just carbon

recItems.blurb: As the title says, it's required.
recItems.headline: *Required Reading: Climate Justice, Adaptation and Investing in Indigenous Power*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: What if I told you everything you know about nature-based solutions is appropriated Indigenous knowledge?
recItems.headline: "The Problem With Nature-Based Solutions"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: In the US, a majority of voters agree that Tribal Nations should be involved in federal conservation efforts.
recItems.headline: "This Earth Day, Biden Must Center Indigenous Voices to Live Up to Climate Promises"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE
recItems.note:
Julia Jeanty and Jade Begay
Data for Progress, 2022

nodes.whoTheyAre: Jade Begay is an Indigenous rights and climate policy expert, organizer and filmmaker.
nodes.whyListen: Jade Begay, Diné and Tesuque Pueblo, is the director of policy and advocacy at NDN Collective, an Indigenous-led organization dedicated to building Indigenous power. She has partnered with Tribal Nations and Indigenous communities on issues like climate justice and Indigenous self-determination. In 2021, she was appointed by President Biden to serve on the first White House Environmental Justice Advisory Council.

videoData.description: Jade Begay works with the people affected first and worst by the climate crisis: Indigenous communities from the Arctic to the Amazon. In a call to align climate action with the needs of those on the frontlines, she offers two starting points to understand how climate change impacts these communities and how their expertise could guide sustainable solutions built on trust.
videoData.socialDescription: Jade Begay works with the people affected first and worst by the climate crisis: Indigenous communities from the Arctic to the Amazon. In a call to align climate action with the needs of those on the frontlines, she offers two starting points to understand how climate change impacts these communities and how their expertise could guide sustainable solutions built on trust.
